admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund:
TF025228-PHRD-PUBLIC FINANCIAL
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF027135-PHRD - SECOND PUBLIC FINANCIAL
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Public Finance
            Management Project for Turkey were as follows; the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that substantial commitment and
            support is required from the highest levels of government in
            a project involving institutional development, the
            restructuring of the organizations, systems and procedures
            for economic management and public finance and introducing
            change on a massive scale in several key ministries and
            agencies. Comprehensiveness of the reform agenda, as
            envisaged in the original design, ensured that all relevant
            areas are covered and all key issues addressed. However, the
            resultant complexity and extended scope made project
            implementation very difficult. The availability of qualified
            and committed high level and influential staff at the
            Treasury and the Customs departments was a major factor in
            the smooth and efficient implementation of these components.
            Bank and the Government counterparts worked closely to be
            flexible, adjust the project scope and settle for a more
            gradual pace of reform and more modest objectives in some
            areas, in order to better match the scope to implementation
            capacity. As mentioned above, the close linkages between the
            PFMP and public sector adjustment lending (the PFPSAL
            program) have been particularly useful in focusing high
            level Government management attention on the importance of
            achieving milestones in the PFMP project. Conversely, The
            project closing date had to be extended by two and a half
            years to complete the activities under the various
            components. The time actually taken to introduce changes in
            the legal framework and organization structures, re-engineer
            functional processes and introduce new systems, procedures
            on such a large scale across multiple government agencies
            needs to be recognized in planning similar projects.
